bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton and Company, April 15, 1730

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to John Pemberton and Company, April 15, 1730, concerning the final financial details of sales of slaves on their ship Rose.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton and Company, April 15, 1730

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
April 15. 1730
Mr. John Pemberton & Compa
Freightr: of the Ship Rose

div1.p:
I receiv'd your favour of the 15th of Decr
per Capt Loxam owning the receipt of the tobo I had Shipt you
and the payment of the money I had order'd you in the hands
of Mr Pemberton for the three protested bills. also you acquain
t me with the receipt of the two hhds sent in Ireland which
were upon the Accot of your goods left with me by Capt
Christian and made up Six hhds on that Accot Marked N[umber]s per letters
the rest of them goods I have lately sold at a lump to Mr Thomas Edwards
they amount to between 5 & 6000 pounds of tobo he is to pay me this
year I hope to get it of him to ship in Breakhill for you

In mine of the 20th of June I acquainted Mr Pemberton
the ballance of your negroe Concern was two thousand and eig
hty one pounds of tobacco herein I send you a bill of Lading for
2 hogsheads weighing neat with the Allowance of Cask 1973. In the Loyalty
Capt Loxum which Ballances that Concern to 109 a parcel of
109 pounds Tobo there is due to the Receivers for a pritty deal of the
tobo of your Concern which I shall send you in my next One
of the Receivers being dead I cannot send you The Accot at Present
I am
div1.closer:
Gentlemen Your most humble Servant
1st letter
per Loxum

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

Carter had acted beginning in the fall of 1727 as local agent for the sale of slaves from the ship Rose owned by Pemberton and some of the merchant's partners. Concluding the financial details of the sale extended over serveral years. See Carter's letter to Pemberton of 1727 September 16 which notes the beginning of the arrangement. Details are mentioned in numerous letters to Pemberton thereafter.

[1] Several vessels named The Loyalty sailed to Virginia. Captain Loxom commanded a vessel of this name in 1729-1730 as did James Tarleton in 1731. (Survey Report 9727, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. See Carter's letter to John Pemberton1731 August 4.)

[2] "Thos. Edwards, a little petty Fogging Lawyer the Clark of our County that hath as much Mettle and more cunning for Contention then his predecessor had" Carter wrote to Landon Jones, July 22, 1723. His opinion of Edwards later changed for there are more appreciative mentions of him in Carter's diary. Edwards was clerk of the Lancaster County court from 1720-1746. (Within the Court House at Lancaster. Lively, VA: Lively Printing Services, Lively, VA: Lively Printing Services, [1976]. p. 15.; and "Thomas Edwards, Gentleman, Clerk of the Court." Brown. Virginia Baron. . . . pp. 94-103.)

[3] There were several vessels with the name Rappahannock. Carter's letters mention a Captain Hugh Brackhill in 1728-1729, and Captain Loxum in 1733. (Adm. 68/194, ff.30, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
